item.title: BTC dumping? Don’t care. It’s temporary. — 69 replies — 276.0/hr

BTC dumping? Don’t care. It’s temporary.

OP

If it drops, I buy more. If it goes sideways, I accumulate. If it pumps, I chill. I’m earning yield and stacking long term.

Investors aren't comfortable holding cash, but that mindset will change once they realise they are holding all of it.

Once the mindset changes, suddenly the liquidity is gone. The rug is pulled. A black hole opens up underneath asset prices.

item.title: Deutsche Bank is "significantly increasing" the integration of XRPL — 12 replies — 30.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Deutsche Bank is "significantly increasing" the integration of XRPL

Open thread • Replies: 12 • Updated: 2026-02-20 14:34 UTC

OP

>https://x.com/boerseonline/status/2024123097222189343
>Deutsche Bank is opening a new chapter in the modernization of global finance. By significantly increasing the integration of technologies from the Ripple ecosystem, the Frankfurt-based bank aims to fundamentally reform the structures of worldwide money transfers, which are often criticized as outdated. The focus is not only on cross-border payments, but also on the complex foreign exchange business as well as the secure custody of digital assets.

Early replies (first 3)

61873420
Honestly, you can hate and FUD XRP all you want, but Ripple is making huge progress and XRP holders will be rewarded sooner rather than later.

61873425
>>61873420
>>61873412
Saaar tumor banks!

61873453
>>61873412
>>61873420
>>61873425
Ripple literally pays banks like Deutsche bank toi announce this bullshit. Nothing is happening.
>Während klassische Überweisungen oft mehrere Tage in Anspruch nehmen, verkürzt die neue Infrastruktur diesen Prozess auf wenige Sekunden.
No bank transfer still takes days ripple still has the 2012 narrative
>Dies bietet enorme Vorteile für Multi-Währungs-Konten und den globalen Devisenhandel, da Liquidität nun in Echtzeit bereitgestellt werden kann.
Complete bullshit word salat this is solved already.
>Schätzungen gehen davon aus, dass der Einsatz von Distributed-Ledger-Technologie (DLT) die operativen Kosten im globalen Zahlungsverkehr um bis zu 30 Prozent senken kann.
So 30% less costs to transfer
And then they talk about the volume of these transfers to have trillions as connection but these are not the transfer costs.
>Die Deutsche Bank nutzt nun Blockchain-Lösungen, die durch die Technologie von Ripple angetrieben werden, um diese Reibungsverluste zu eliminieren
Read very carefully. Deutsche Bank uses Blockchain. Ripple advances Blockchain technology. Thats means Deustche Bank likely uses Ethereum kek.

61876817
>>61875563
It's an interesting theory that borders on coping strategy because it makes currency seem much more important than the worthless shit it is. Yuan floating or not floating does not change the fact that China manufactures everything that's not manufactured elsewhere. The currency that is used in the exchange of goods does not change that fact. The unfloating of yuan would not teleport all the CNC mills, supply chains, and millions of workers into Tennessee or Germany. Currency can ligma balls or be infinitely expensive compared to other currencies, it does not matter. It may seem that it does, but it does not. Fixed currency makes exchange of goods easier, and manufacturers can plan more easily. Exchange rates are annoying, that's true. China eliminated that headache. It's a right decision, but nowhere near the most important decision they made to be the best at everything that matters.

61876956
>>61874655
>the US can literally print the oil price into the ground
it can't actually. Picrel. Being able to produce 70% of the all physical things on Earth give you the ability to print whatever you want WITHOUT inflation.

>>61874440

I sincerely hope you're just too young or pol-brained to know any better, but just in case you aren't:

The Chinese state does not give out money (or make sure other financiers are available to give out money) in order to create productive, competitive industry. They do it for 2 reasons:
>It lets them massively overproduce a good (solar panels, EVs, E-bikes, ect...) at a loss in order to crush foreign manufacturing bases and corner the production
>It helps ensure employment.

Half the reason for the boondoggle that has been OBOR is that it meant the Chinese could use central Asia as a dumping ground for all of the dogshit concrete and steel they were churning out at a loss for years. There wasn't an appetite for that much material when they were making it, and they knew it. Export profits were not the point.

The 2nd point is the bigger deal. Basically, for a long time, the deal in China was that so long as the average guy could get a job if he wanted one, and didn't make too much noise, things would get better. The CCP revolution that conquered the country was built on jobless, angry people, and the guys running the CCP did not want to be on the other end of that deal. Therefore, the CCP is willing to subsidize terrible business that are guaranteed to lose money, so long as they can promise jobs. The problem these days is that youth unemployment is high and climbing and the increasingly small share of the Chinese population that is young is more and more dissatisfied with living in a PvE server as the E.

>61876817
>best at everything that matters

You would think that they would just incinerate the waste solvents from all the REE processing like Victorian industrialists, but I guess it was 0.000003 RMB cheaper per ton to just dump it into the nearest waterway.

61877619
>>61872964
Instead of wasting money on niggers, China subsidizes real businesses that make things?
IMF Jews are seething.

61877897
>>61876817
I am not arguing that China doesn’t produce essential goods. I am trying to explain how these conditions happened. While there are tons of reasons that Chinese manufacturing rose to prominence—huge cheap labor force that was previously kept away from foreign investment, America putting China on the MFN list—a consistently cheap currency is one of them, hence why they have been accused of currency manipulation for literal decades.

>Currency can ligma balls or be infinitely expensive compared to other currencies, it does not matter. It may seem that it does, but it does not.
This is just patently untrue. Obviously, if China’s currency were infinitely expensive, which would be the equivalent to having a self-imposed trade embargo, nobody would buy their products. What you would see is the rapid expansion of the industries that China has a monopoly on; a part of the reason that these industries do not pop up elsewhere is that potential manufacturers know that it’s difficult to compete with how cheap Chinese goods are, so why bother.

You seem to genuinely believe that exchange rates do not ultimately matter in trade, which simply ignores how international trade functions. I’ll give you another example. After WWII, the US set Japan’s exchange rate intentionally low as a part of the Dodge Plan because they wanted a democratic stronghold in Asia, and they knew giving them a cheaper currency would help their export market. This worked TOO WELL. Over the course of the next forty years, Japan became so dominant in the export market that other countries began to panic and they “renegotiated” the exchange rate again at the plaza accords (this would have disastrous effects). If we were in the 80’s, you would point to Japan and say that “look at all the great products they make. It doesn’t matter what their exchange rate is,” and that would ignore the conditions that gave rise to their export dominance in the first place.

>>61872971

61878162
>>61878109
They made a bet that reaching out infrastructure to the hundreds of millions of people of low-productivity regions could improve domestic demand to the extent that their subsidies start to be consumed internally. The problem is that the low-productivity areas are, of course, low income and the only two options which exist to them are:
>Direct UBI for low-income areas
>Creating even more highly subsidized factories to employ low-income people and give them a better wage
Honestly for them the UBI route is likely more cost-effective, to avoid further deflating the value of the plants they already have. The 3rd (much) more challenging and expensive option would be to migrate the sweat-shops and low-skill factories out to the countryside from bigger city centers and reassign the existing factories to high-tech, high-skill plants such as chip foundries and advanced component manufacturing. To a certain extent they're being forced into this already due to sanctions etc on high-end chips, but if it's their primary gameplan then it's progressing way too slowly. Modernizing a billion people (bugs) is a hell of a project

item.title: why would anyone live here — 87 replies — 59.6/hr

why would anyone live here

Open thread • Replies: 87 • Updated: 2026-02-20 13:30 UTC

OP

i recently moved to NYC to work for a "lucrative salary" (not really, because this place drains you of all your income) and after working here for 4 months i dont know why anyone would willingly live here

>the entire city smells like rotting shit, cigarette buds and dead animals, not a faint smell, an extremely strong odor that you'll eventually just become nose blind to

>homeless people, fucking everywhere, when i left my apartment there were homeless people sleeping in the hallways of my complex, when you go on walk there are homeless people sleeping on the sidewalk with a PILLOW and BLANKET while regular people walk over them like this is just some normal fucking occurrence (and in this shithole it is) never ever have i seen some shit like this even in the worst of cities ive lived in.

>heroin needles, weed bags, cigarette buds & the occasional dildo just scattered across the city sidewalks, your constantly walking over human shit, broken bottles or dime bags

>rats and rodents EVERYWHERE. il never forget the time i bought a pizza from one of the disgusting street vendors and when i sat down at a table one of the rats were circling my feet trying to climb my leg for a bite.

>the "public transport" system is a just permanent housing for the mentally ill, every time i had to ride the subway i was scared for my life because of all the fucking looneys that inhabit the train systems

this is just off the top of my head, but i think the biggest mindfuck of it all is that its EXPENSIVE to live here its gonna cost you not 50k, not 100k, not 200k, to live comfortably by yourself you need 250K yearly in manhattan. 250k, to live among violent homeless people, 250k to constantly have to walk in rotting shit and roadkill. 250k to have your ears blown out by car horns & niggerbabble, 250k to be forced to smell the most putried scents imaginable i dont know why anyone sane would live here, this place is some sort of social experiment, some sort of anonmoly.

All taxation is theft. It's just that. Taxation doesn't pay for services. It's just the way they control the economy, and here in EU they fucking LOVE to control what you can and cannot do. They print the money, they don't need to tax you. They tax you to control you (and to humiliate you)

it started long before post-WW2 tho, germs bureaucracymaxxed post-reunification during the 2nd Reich, from 1871 onward.
At first it was to keep in check all the landers trying to take the lion's share of federal credits and centralize power. And it worked gud, but then it progressively became the hellscape kafkaian machine we all know.
That's how you know the hallofcost never happened, becuz you can be sure nazis would have made endless paperworks addressing the situation, down to the very last jewish pubic hair, but we didn't find any document.

61870778
Stop eating the commie propaganda. Europeans don't have savings for shit, they just have stable expenses but all their wealth is tied to inheriting homes. That's why homes are basically untaxed while stocks are treated like financial Nazism. You aren't going to spend more a healthy young person in the US, the real benefit of Europe is the private healthcare is very cheap and good

Starting businesses in Europe sucks because of two factors. The first is low liquidity and consumer spending: unlike the US, people don't spend nearly as much, have as much to spend, or make debt. So there isn't much room for anyone to buy something new - successful businesses target liquid tourists or B2B, where they write off the huge taxes as expenses. Over regulated financial market also leads to lower liquidity and more difficulty getting loans and investors, you rely on government programs run by middle aged menopausal cunts that have never worked more than 28 hours a week

Other issue is labor laws and public perception. It's morally bankrupt to try and get more money, why aren't you happy being average, why are you trying to pull ahead. Anyone you hire can't be fired, you can't have low compensation with offset packages to get high skill labor, you need to suck some blue blooded cock to get money and not wait years for whatever permits you'll need, because they were born out of nobility and still have half the money and connections

Eurotards freak out about Epstein but every European politician and rich person rapes babies for breakfast. It's just 1) not pedo to them if they're over 14 bc muh age of consent and 2) they hide in the shadows unlike Americans, they try to be as unnoticed as possible, give a few concessions to the poor and continue ruling sucking and fucking like they've been doing the past thousand years

61870889
>>61870103
What are the reforms that boomers are blocking?

61870915
>>61869942
Yeah i feel the same. Sex, drugs and love are already the ultimate sensations and none of them are expensive. All luxuries are pretty worthless add-ons and don’t feel special. You just have a bigger bed, or a bigger car, not anything you really need.

61870937
>>61860817
That's complete bullshit, stop making up fantasies in your mind. If there is ONE thing still somewhat running smoothly in western Europe, it's free healthcare.
Contrary to you i know what i'm talking about since i was on the operation table just a month ago to fix few lower vertebrae after a bike accident. I never had to wait for anything more than few days, nor did i have to spend a single penny on pre-procedures, examinations or for the hospital stay/operation/anesthesia/post-op medication. And i don't have any health mutual.

It probably would have costed me a bazillion goybux in the jewSA.

61871000
>>61870937
Why the fuck would it cost bajillions, even shit insurance has a max out of pocket of like 10k. If you don't have a job medicaid literally covers everything for free, the real problem is half the people that qualify are too fucking stupid to sign up for it

Also if the accident wasn't your fault you could sue for big money, in Europe they're just like meh accidents happen enjoy the lifelong complications faggot. I will agree southern European health systems are pretty decent and their private healthcare is fantastic and cheap, but if you're German or some shit I'd rather have the US system, you guys pay more in healthcare tax than any American if you have a half decent job and if you get anything where you may actually die they just say, yeah you're fucked settle your affairs or the bureaucracy will give the rest of your family a stroke, no point trying any more it's an inefficient allocation of resources

61871020
>>61868041
This is extremely short-sighted of them, they will end up losing the capacity to compete and fall behind slowly, they actually already are, then when they slowly go on closing business left and right from ever increasing ineficiency. What else can they even do but borrow more and more for the worst possible spending a state can do, paying bills, a budget blackhole, increasing inflation and making money useless and as those countries get poorer the services will also get far far far worse and extremely corrupt, not even talking about how such aging will make it even worse. Honestly this is reading like what happened to argentina, greece and other latam and thirdies socialist govts did, it will work fine as long as the economy can keep it, when it starts to shrink it will be poverty hell. I will agree that america treats us workers pretty bad, but this welfare paradise of the EU won't work for long either, they will end up forced to cut things and get closer to us if they want to survive a world with China, India, US and former colonies being no longer mudhutts but mildly developed enough to make raw resources more expensive.

61871023
>>61860796
Lots of retards ITT.

Setting up a business is child's play in places like Denmark, Sweden, Estonia. Setting up, doing tax returns and all interactions with gov is handled through online ID and takes seconds.

Places like Bulgaria, Romania, Slovenia are selling themselves as business friendly. Very low taxes. Some places like Bulgaria have extremely low dividend taxes so you pay yourself with dividends. Romania has a corporate setup where you pay a tiny percentage on the turnover. Ideal for freelancers or small business with high margins or just extreme low expense. In all of these places, corporate setups and accountants cost next to nothing.

Then you have some almost offshore jurisdictions still in the EU with insanely beneficial rules for some niches and very low taxes. Like Cyprus and Malta.

Now regulations, what regulations? Anything (except guns, booze, some gambling, cigarettes I guess) is traded freely between the states under the same legislation.

Also: we get sued way less over here. Do the math on that one.

61871050
> wife started selling her paintings
> she declared herself first, this was needed to attend some events
> French government instantly asks her for €800, before she has made her first sale
> this is what they estimate she'd owe them at the end of the year based on their estimates of how much she will earn, so they ask for it upfront
> you can contest it but it's actually faster to wait for the year to end so they are proven wrong
I hate them so much...

61871051
>>61860860
>taxes
depends where, some places will legit rape your revenue
Combined with some insane regulations and you legit can't start a company
Best example is France, fucked up taxes, and if you want to get into tech, or anything that involves personal data, you need cough up 6 to 7 figures so that your cyber security is in the norm

61871089
>>61860815
This

61871111
>>61871020
I will die long before I see some high tech company or even mid tier industry appear in latam, africa or even india, they will always be turning up cheap raw resources because they are simply brown subhumans with low iq, not even talking about russia post-war. Its an unfounded fearmongering that we will ever have to compete with them lol, you forget europe will never fall to thirdie level of mismanagement simple because we are better educated and white. At the very worst unlikely scenario we will always make money from tourism anyway, but honestly this is all american envy for no reason, we are not stopping you from doing the same.

61871116
>>61871023
So you're admitting you can only live off arbitrage? Who the fuck are you selling to in Romania or Bulgaria, Romania is actually marginally based because it's spread its asshole to US companies for cheap EU labor, those Nordic countries you listed have a smaller economy than Pennsylvania so yeah if you want to sell troon support stickers you're good but you're not going to make shit otherwise

Portugal is also kind of based but it fully relies on US and other European investments, as well as inexistent enforcement of labor laws and pathetic salaries. I don't get how you'd start up there without the first 100k being gifted though, or the family having land, or working abroad first

As I said, Europe is only viable for tourism or B2B, you will never become a millionaire opening a bakery or car wash or hamster fentanyl university of arts like the US, there's no consumer spending to eat

61871180
>>61871116
>Europe is only viable for tourism or B2B, you will never become a millionaire
Lmao, just look at economic charts, most european economies have high tech industry as the main economic activity, american bullshit as usual, nobody needs to be a millionaire in europe, we already live better than one.

61871183
>>61871116
>Who the fuck are you selling to in Romania or Bulgaria,
As I said, you are a fucking retard. Your company is in Bulgaria, but you sell to fucking anyone in EU the same way while paying insanely low corporate tax and next to no admin fees. You ship from anywhere you want in the EU, or have staff in bloody Manila if you wish. What the fuck does that have to do with arbitrage? You incorporate wherever you want since it is your legal right.

I doubt you are entrepreneurial material though, so do not bother grokking the potential here.

61871191
>>61871000
The suing thing is the biggest AIDS of USA. People are already well compensated enough in europe for their troubles. The ”if you make a honest mistake, someone will see their opportinity and sue you and financially destroy your life” mentality just creates even more stress to an already high stress environment of USA. It just makes people act even more legally defensive at every turn and creates useless bureucracy and slows things down. Getting raped when everything didn’t go 100% nicely is not something to be proud of.

61871214
>>61871020
This is the most midwit take and the reason why USA is failing now (it has become a nation of midwits due to poor public education). People have been saying this for decades but right now europe is in a bullrun while USA has been becoming an oligarchic brasil since the 80s. Clearly socialism doesn't just lead to inefficiency but instead to more efficiency for all instead of just few hoarding the wealth.

61871353
>>61871183
Learn to read Fritz, you are saying what I'm saying while sounding like a mong. You're setting up in poor countries to sell to richer countries' businesses while using the common market, it's geographic arbitrage you sausage guzzling troon, and you're selling to businesses. All that free education and you're still poorer than a fucking car salesman in Pensacola

61871500
>>61871214

Excluding Pooland all major eu economies have stopped growing or deacelerated fast, people were saying it for decades with reason, if it wasnt for a miraculous fall of the ussr and a flood of cheap raw resources and energy with negligible transport costs from russia it would've happened earlier as it did post-2008 when europe started to lag more and more behind the US and China.

61871533

ok, well, how much

you just said you don't know what I owe

so how do you know if I pay wrong?

Half of every country is too fucking poor to pay tax, and the top 10% isn't stupid enough to pay tax, so the middle class just pays 50% of their income while being happy they can rent a shit hole for life and that they're better off unemployed than working in terms of life quality

item.title: Finding a Career — 6 replies — 15.3/hr
item.content:encoded:
Finding a Career

Open thread • Replies: 6 • Updated: 2026-02-20 14:34 UTC

OP

I'm looking for a career and found an outstanding position as a pizza delivery driver. I was expecting a simple application process to match the prestigious job position, but was taken aback at the first step! HR is doing a darn fine job at preventing anyone from being hired!

Early replies (first 3)

61877003
>>61876930
>can't pass a basic test to see if you're a psycho or not
sounds like a you problem

61877090
>>61876930
>can't pass a basic test to see if you're a psycho or not
sounds like a you problem

61877094
>>61876930
Have you been an employer lately? If you dont absolutely vet them, then you will end up with some shitskin that doesn't pay taxes. And if you dont hire them because they are in fact that, you still get sued.

>>61877094
